message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of a pedunculated mass arising from the endometrium with well-demarcated borders is consistent with an endometrial polyp. Endometrial carcinoma would present with more concerning symptoms and features, and adenomyosis would not appear as a pedunculated mass. Endometrial hyperplasia may present with abnormal bleeding but not necessarily as a mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has intermenstrual bleeding and a pedunculated mass arising from the endometrium, which suggests an endometrial polyp. Endometrial carcinoma would have irregular borders and be more invasive, while adenomyosis would have diffuse thickening of the endometrium. Endometrial hyperplasia would have a diffuse thickening of the endometrium as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is consistent with an endometrial polyp, which is a benign growth of endometrial tissue. The well-demarcated borders and pedunculated nature suggest a benign nature, and intermenstrual bleeding is a common symptom of these growths. The lack of other symptoms or findings suggests that malignancy or other pathologies are less likely.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the mass as pedunculated with well-demarcated borders is characteristic of an endometrial polyp, which is a common cause of intermenstrual bleeding. Endometrial carcinoma may present with bleeding, but the features described here are not consistent with that diagnosis. Adenomyosis is a condition in which the endometrium grows into the myometrium and causes heavy bleeding and painful periods. Endometrial hyperplasia is an overgrowth of the endometrium that can lead to abnormal bleeding, but it is not usually pedunculated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of a red beefy pedunculated mass arising from the endometrium with well-demarcated borders is consistent with an endometrial polyp. Endometrial carcinoma presents with irregular borders, uterine adenomyosis with diffuse thickening of the uterine wall, and endometrial hyperplasia with thickening of the endometrial lining.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of a red beefy pedunculated mass with well-demarcated borders arising from the endometrium is consistent with an endometrial polyp. Endometrial carcinoma and hyperplasia do not typically present as a pedunculated mass, while adenomyosis is not a visible mass but rather a diffuse thickening of the uterus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the description, the most likely diagnosis is an endometrial polyp, which often presents with intermenstrual bleeding and a well-demarcated pedunculated mass. Endometrial carcinoma, adenomyosis, and hyperplasia often present with other symptoms and have different characteristics on diagnostic imaging. Histopathological examination will confirm the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the mass suggests an endometrial polyp, which is a benign growth that arises from the endometrium. Endometrial carcinoma is a malignant tumor and adenomyosis involves infiltration of the endometrium into the myometrium. Endometrial hyperplasia involves the proliferation of the endometrial glands and stroma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and the diagnostic hysteroscopy findings suggest an endometrial polyp. Endometrial carcinoma is less likely given the well-demarcated borders, and there are no other symptoms or signs to suggest adenomyosis or hyperplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of small volume intermenstrual bleeding with a pedunculated mass arising from the endometrium of the uterus suggests the most likely diagnosis is an endometrial polyp. The well-demarcated borders also support this diagnosis. Endometrial carcinoma is less likely as there are no other symptoms and there is no mention of abnormal cells on histopathological examination. Uterine adenomyosis and endometrial hyperplasia would not present with a visible mass.
